title: Can you call a former president Mr. President? - Quora

response.answer_text: In the United States, as there is but a single person holding the Office of the President at a time, referring to former Presidents as “Mr. President” is incorrect. Strictly speaking, you would address such former officeholders different things, depending on the situation. If addressing a letter to them, or introducing them to another person, the person is “The Honorable <firstname> <lastname>”. When using a 3rd person reference, this is the correct form. It may be shortened by replacing the <firstname> with a Mr./Mrs./Ms. I.e when sending a letter to Bill Clinton, it should have “The Honorable William J Clinton” on the outside. When introducing your partner to him, it should be “This is the Honorable Mr. Clinton”.If talking directly to them, they should be named “Mr/Mrs/Ms <lastname>”. In addition, this should also be used when referring to the person in any form of media or conversation when the person is not present. I.e. Bill Clinton should be referred to as “Mr. Clinton” in current day news reports.They should be referred to as “President <lastname>” when talking about them in the historical timeframe during which they were President. I.e. “President Clinton failed to reach an agreement with Speaker Gingrich”In extremely formal situations, it’s entirely proper to refer to the former president as: “The Honorable Mr. William J Clinton, former President of the United States of America.”Face to face, if you happen to be a buddy of the former President, well, calling them whatever you two want. “Bubba”, “Bill”, “Old Rotten Scoundrel” or whatever tickles the two of you’s fancy.Many former Presidents are addressed as “President <lastname>”, but this it not correct, as there is only a single President at once, and that form of address is confusing. It’s an informal convention to do so, however, and unless the CURRENT President is also part of the conversation (or present), it’s generally let slide.

As with all things related to politeness and etiquette, there is no universally agreed upon answer on how to address a former president. In formal settings, we address the current president as Mr. President or Madame President[1]. John Adams wanted the president to go by the title of “His Highness, the President of the United States, and Protector of the Rights of the Same,” but a congressman pointed out the Constitution's prohibition on title's of nobility, and they decided on the more reserved "Mr. President."[2] There does not appear to be a solid consensus on what we should call former presidents. Some claim that the Constitution's prohibition against titles of nobility means we should not use "Mr. President" when addressing a former president[3][4]. Instead, we are supposed to use titles like "Mr. Bush" or "Senator Obama." Others claim that former presidents hold the title after they leave office and therefore should be addressed as "Mr. President."[5] This is based on the tradition of addressing a person by the highest office they held. This is further reinforced by the press and other forms of media using the title of "Mr. President" when addressing former presidents. As an average American, I do not think what we call a former president matters in the grand scheme of things. In everyday conversation, I do not worry about formal titles. When referring to former presidents, I use names like JFK, FDR, LBJ, Tricky Dick, Jimmy Carter, Bush Sr., Bill Clinton, Slick Willie, Bush Jr., Bush Lite, and Obama. We do not have kings and nobility in America, so I do not feel the need to worry about using formal titles. If I ever met Barack Obama (or any of the former presidents for that matter) in person, I would ask one of their aides what title they prefer. If I were not given any guidance, I would go with Mr. Obama as it is a safe and uncontroversial choice. Yess you can. You can add the word former if you like. Or you can simple refer or address him Mr. “Whatever”. But of course you can refer to or address a current President Mr. “Whatever” as well. However protocol, tradition and respect for the office dictate the use of the honorific. With few exceptions once a title is earned, a person is permitted to continue to use it. Even Presidents refer to and address their predecessors this way. Bill Clinton, Barack Obama, George HW Bush, George W Bush and even Richard Nixon are still referred to as President Clinton, President Obama, President Bush, President Bush and even President Nixon. And they are, in Nixon's case were, addressed as Mr. President.

Watch the Sunday morning political talk shows. Former administration honchos are addressed with the highest “political” title that they had. … So, (spoiler) yes, not only can you, but you should. Examples (address them as): President ClintonPresident Bush (1 & 2)President Obama

Yes. The office continues to be the title. So Obama would be introduced, for example, with “we have former President Obama with us today,” but then addressed as, “So, Mr. President, what do you think of…”. It's why HRC is addressed as Madam Secretary, etc.

Yes. In fact, it is what you are supposed to do. All presidents are considered to be presidents from the moment they are sworn in indefinitely. Even Richard Nixon was called President Nixon. I suppose if a president was impeached they would not be called Mr. President anymore, however, no president has been impeached to date.

well we can say him Mr. President ,not only for the position that he held but in the memory of what kind of legacy he left in serving his country and also in respect to what he might have gone through during his job of working for others ,the toughest job.
You could, but it would be incorrect. If you were to meet Obama right now, you would call him Barack if you were his friend and Mr Obama if you were being formal/if you were a child
No. Only the current president is addressed as “Mr. President”. After leaving office, the former president is properly addressed by his former title, e.g. “Mr. Truman”.

You could call a random citizen “Mr. President.” Less exclusive of a title but plenty of people refer to others as “boss” for no real reason. In the end, a title is just a word and as such can be assigned to anyone or anything whether correct or not.
That will be politically incorrect. There can be only be one President and that’s the current one. The former will revert back to his civilian identity.
Yes. Any former President that appears on “The Talking Heads” on Sunday’s are addressed as “Mr. President”.
